subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Parralel Systems
msgSnippet: ... I have been reading through the QS manual again recently, and it actually seems a bit disorganized to me.  When Read is talking about Senior Quickscript,
messageBody:
On 20 Jul 2006, at 15:27, pgabhart wrote:
I see the distinction between senior and junior as similar to that of printed T.O. and cursive T.O.  In the past, cursive was not practical to use for printed material so almost everything was printed in disconnected letters.  Cursive writing was reserved for handwriting.  But that is no longer necessary.  Computer technology should be able to make the use of senior forms relatively easy, so why should we not use the senior form in material printed for proficient readers? 

I have been reading through the QS manual again recently, and it actually seems a bit disorganized to me.  When Read is talking about Senior Quickscript, he is actually talking about two separate things: cursive/joined writing, and common contractions/abbreviations/affixes.  Certainly the latter is possible using a 'junior' unconnected character set just as much as it would be using connected characters, and so I believe that need no longer be considered 'senior' but rather just a basic trait of the writing system.

A better way for presenting the alphabet, and learning it as well, would be to swap Read's second and third section, presenting them in this order:
* the characters
* contractions/abbreviations/affixes
* cursive writing and alternate glyphs

I do agree that (in concept) the use of connected writing should be possible (and preferable) using computers... though in practice it is has been difficult for me to figure out how to make the computer do that automatically.

oliver

a test:

            ,      .   ,       ,        .             .


